   Assessment and Plan
 PULMONARY EDEMA
 ATRIAL FIBRILLATION (AFIB)
 HYPERTENSION, BENIGN
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)
 MULTIPLE MYELOMA  (CANCER, MALIGNANT NEOPLASM)
   Assessment and Plan
   75-year-old woman with history of hypertension and multiple myeloma,
   presents to ICU with tachycardia to 180s this AM in setting of multiple
   refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier in hospital
   course.
   #. Tachycardia:
   Per cardiology read of EKG on admission to the ICU, patient's curent
   rhythm is atypical atrial flutter with variable conduction to
   ventricles. She has certainly had atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier
   in her hospital course. Possible that her recent episodes of atrial
   fib/flutter are due to or exacerbated by volume overload. Current
   evidence of overload is pulmonary edema, peripheral edema, JVP
   elevation, increasing weight. Complicating her tachycardia is her
   fever, which was as high as 102.1 early this AM. Regarding long-term
   managment of atrial fib/flutter, her CHADS2 score is 2 (age and
   hypertension) and she will eventually require consideration for
   anticoagulation, though platelet count of 12 precludes that currently.
   - Diltiazem drip
   - Control fever as much as possible
   - Diueresis given her clinical exam consistent with volume overload and
   her pulmonary edema per recent CT scan
   - Daily weights
   - Appreciate cardiology input
   #. Altered mental status:
   Most consistent with delirium, though fevers are concerning for
   possible CNS infection.  Patient reportedly withdrawing compared to
   prior interactions with healthcare teams. Concerning that her mental
   status changes are coming in setting of PLT count of 14 and 12 in last
   two days. Additional consideration that patient is having febrile
   neutropenia and encephalitis or meningitis could be contributing.
   - STAT head CT
   - Follow-up PLT count
   - Increase cefepime to Q8H and increase daptomycin to 6 mg/kg for
   additional CNS coverage
   - Consider MRI if ongoing concern for infectious etiologies of AMS
   - Consider neurology consult if no clearing of mental status
   #. Hypoxia:
   Patient with new oxygen requirement in the last few days. Currently
   mid-90s on 3L NC. Pulmonary exam with upper airway coarse sounds and
   bilbasilar crackles. Possible that hypoxia is all due to pulmonary
   edema from poor LV filling in setting of LVH and tachycardia.
   - Control HR and BP as above
   - Trend supplemental oxygen requirement with diuersis and resolution of
   tachycardia as above
   - CXR to assess for any focal consolidation
   #. Multiple Myeloma s/p now stem cell transplant:
   Patient is SCT day +6.
   - Appreciate BMT team input into further management
   - Transplant precautions
   - Low bacteria diet
   #. Febrile neutropenia:
   Patient's ANC this AM was 5. Tmax in last 24 hours was 102.1 at 0100
   today. Prior to transfer to ICU, temperature was down to 99.9.
   - Neutropenic precautions
   - Continue neupogen until ANC greater than 1000
   - Continue micafungin (currently day 5), cefepime (currently day 8),
   daptomycin (currently day 4), acyclovir (currently day 9)
   #. VRE UTI:
   Urine culture positive from [**2112-1-23**]. Sensitive to linezolid;
   however, BMT did not want to use linezolid due to marrow suppression.
   Daptomycin was started on [**2112-1-26**] and daptomycin sensitivies are
   pending.
   - ID consult input appreciated
   - Continue daptomycin (currently day 4)
   - Await urine culture sensitivities for daptomycin
   #. Thrombocytopenia:
   Patient received a bag of platelets this AM for PLT count of 12.
   - Post-transfusion PLT count
   - Trend PLTs
   #. Hypertension:
   End-organ damage given LVH on EKGs. Patient has not had hypotension
   during her current course.
   - Additional diuresis as above
   - Consider afterload reduction with IV hydralazine if blood pressure
   greater than 150s systolic while on diltiazem drip
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Regular low bacteria diet as allowed by her mucositis, TPN
   w/ Lipids - [**2112-1-28**] 10:49 AM 65 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control: [**Hospital1 7**] FSBS with HISS
   Lines: Tunneled (Hickman) Line - [**2112-1-28**] 10:50 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   - DVT ppx with pneumoboots
   - Bowel regimen will be added as needed
   - Pain management with PRN morphine IV
   Communication:  [**Name (NI) **] husband, [**Name (NI) 478**] [**Name (NI) 12343**], [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12344**] or
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12345**]
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU for now while requiring diltiazem drip for control of
   atrial fib/flutter

Summary of Progress Note:

- The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and multiple myeloma, presenting to the ICU with tachycardia to 180s this morning.
- She has had multiple refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response earlier in her hospital course.
- Possible that her recent episodes of atrial fib/flutter are due to or exacerbated by volume overload.
- Current evidence of overload includes pulmonary edema, peripheral edema, JVP elevation, and increasing weight.
- She also has a fever, which was as high as 102.1 early this morning.
- Her CHADS2 score is 2 (age and hypertension), and she will eventually require consideration for anticoagulation, though her platelet count of 12 precludes that currently.
- She is currently on diltiazem drip, and her fever is being controlled as much as possible.
- Diuretics are being given due to her clinical exam consistent with volume overload and her pulmonary edema per recent CT scan.
- Daily weights are being appreciated, and cardiology input is being awaited.

- She has certainly had atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier in her hospital course.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and multiple myeloma presenting to the ICU with tachycardia to 180s this AM in the setting of multiple refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response earlier in the hospital course. The patient's current rhythm is atypical atrial flutter with variable conduction to the ventricles. She has also had atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier in her hospital course.

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:
1. Pulmonary edema: The patient has evidence of volume overload, including pulmonary edema, peripheral edema, JVP elevation, and increasing weight. This can lead to respiratory distress and compromised oxygenation.
2. Atrial fibrillation (AFib): The patient has had multiple episodes of AFib with RVR, which can increase the risk of stroke, heart failure, and other cardiovascular complications.
3. Hypertension: The patient has hypertension, which is further complicated by left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) on EKGs. This can lead to end-organ damage if not controlled.
4. Altered mental status (AMS): The patient is withdrawing and experiencing mental status changes, which could be due to several factors such as febrile neutropenia, encephalitis, meningitis, or medication effects.
5. Hypoxia: The patient requires supplemental oxygen and has coarse

   refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier in hospital
   course.
   #. Altered mental status:
   Most consistent with delirium, though fevers are concerning for
   possible CNS infection.  Patient reportedly withdrawing compared to
   prior interactions with healthcare teams. Additional consideration that
   patient is having febrile neutropenia and encephalitis or meningitis
   could be contributing.  CT head was normal, without evidence of bleed.
   Her agitation drives her tachycardia, so we have been intermittently
   using morphine, ativan and haldol to calm her.  She is nearly
   non-verbal, making it difficult to assess her pain.
   - PRN haldol for now, if working well/using regularly, can switch to
   standing dose.
   - Increase cefepime to Q8H and increase daptomycin to 6 mg/kg for
   additional CNS coverage
   - Consider MRI if ongoing concern for infectious etiologies of AMS
   - Continue PRN ativan and morphine.
   - [**Month (only) 51**] consider daptomycin as contributing to delirium.
   #. Tachycardia:
   Today appears to be in Afib with RVR. Possible that her recent episodes
   of atrial fib/flutter are due to or exacerbated by volume overload.
   Current evidence of overload is pulmonary edema, peripheral edema, JVP
   elevation, increasing weight. Complicating her tachycardia is continued
   fever.  CHADS2 score is 2 (age and hypertension), so she will
   eventually require consideration for anticoagulation, though platelet
   count of 12 precludes that currently.
   - Continue diltiazem drip w/ PRN lopressor when not controlled.
   - Consider amiodarone or digoxin.  Amiodarone would likely be more
   effective, but may cause cardioversion and it is impossible to know
   without a TEE or prolonged anticoagulation whether he has a [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **]
   [**Last Name (Prefixes) 5624**].  Digoxin may be more realistic at this point.
   - Control fever as much as possible
   - Continue diuresis as creatinine allows.
   - Daily weights
   - Appreciate cardiology input
   #. Hypoxia:
   Patient with new oxygen requirement in the last few days. Currently
   mid-90s on 3L NC. Pulmonary exam with upper airway coarse sounds and
   bilbasilar crackles. Possible that hypoxia is all due to pulmonary
   edema from poor LV filling in setting of LVH and tachycardia.  This
   hypothesis supported by worsening hypoxia when tachy to 150s.
   - Control HR and BP as above
   - Diuresis as creatinine allows.
   #. Multiple Myeloma s/p now stem cell transplant:
   Patient is SCT day +7.  Will likely nadir until days [**12-19**].
   - Appreciate BMT team input into further management
   - Transplant precautions
   - Low bacteria diet
   #. Febrile neutropenia:
   Patient's ANC now 0. Patient persistently febrile on micafungin,
   cefepime, daptomycin and acyclovir.
   - Neutropenic precautions
   - Continue neupogen until ANC greater than 1000
   - Continue micafungin (currently day 5), cefepime (currently day 8),
   daptomycin (currently day 4), acyclovir (currently day 9)
   #. VRE UTI:
   Urine culture positive from [**2112-1-23**]. Sensitive to linezolid;
   however, BMT did not want to use linezolid due to marrow suppression.
   Daptomycin sensitive, so dapto started on [**2112-1-26**].
   - ID consult input appreciated
   - Continue daptomycin (currently day 4)
   - Await urine culture sensitivities for daptomycin
   #. Hypertension:
   Normal ventricular function on Echo. Patient has not had hypotension
   during her current course.
   - Additional diuresis as above
   - Consider afterload reduction with IV hydralazine once HR controlled
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Regular low bacteria diet as allowed by her mucositis, TPN

   - DVT ppx with pneumoboots
   - Bowel regimen will be added as needed
   - Pain management with PRN morphine IV

Summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old female admitted to the hospital for an auto-SCT (stem cell transplant) complicated by febrile neutropenia, VRE UTI (vancomycin-resistant enterococci urinary tract infection), AMS (acute mental status changes), and mucositis. She was transferred for rapid atrial fibrillation and pulmonary edema. The patient has a history of allergies to Percocet (Oxycodone/Acetaminophen), Ciprofloxacin, Oxycodone, and hallucinations. She is currently on multiple medications including diltiazem, hydralazine, meperidine, furosemide, metoprolol, pantoprazole, morphine sulfate, haloperidol, and lorazepam.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Rapid atrial fibrillation: The patient's rapid atrial fibrillation remains uncontrolled despite diltiazem infusion. The plan is to convert back to oral beta-blocker and control agitation with pain medications and Haldol.
2. Altered mental status: The patient has AMS with some component of delirium. Haldol has been started based on prn needs.
3. Febrile neutropenia: The patient's febrile neutropenia is being covered with cefipime, daptomycin, and micafungin. Further management will be discussed with the BMT/cards team,

 MULTIPLE MYELOMA  (CANCER, MALIGNANT NEOPLASM)
   75-year-old woman with history of hypertension and multiple myeloma,
   presents to ICU with tachycardia to 180s this AM in setting of multiple
   refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier in hospital
   course.
   #. Altered mental status:
   Most consistent with delirium, though fevers are concerning for
   possible CNS infection.  Patient reportedly withdrawing compared to
   prior interactions with healthcare teams. Additional consideration that
   patient is having febrile neutropenia and encephalitis or meningitis
   could be contributing.  CT head was normal, without evidence of bleed.
   Her agitation drives her tachycardia, so we have been intermittently
   using morphine, ativan and haldol to calm her.  She is nearly
   non-verbal, making it difficult to assess her pain.
   - PRN haldol for now, if working well/using regularly, can switch to
   standing dose.
   - Increase cefepime to Q8H and increase daptomycin to 6 mg/kg for
   additional CNS coverage
   - Consider MRI if ongoing concern for infectious etiologies of AMS
   - Continue PRN ativan and morphine.
   - [**Month (only) 51**] consider daptomycin as contributing to delirium.
   #. Tachycardia:
   Today appears to be in Afib with RVR. Possible that her recent episodes
   of atrial fib/flutter are due to or exacerbated by volume overload.
   Current evidence of overload is pulmonary edema, peripheral edema, JVP
   elevation, increasing weight. Complicating her tachycardia is continued
   fever.  CHADS2 score is 2 (age and hypertension), so she will
   eventually require consideration for anticoagulation, though platelet
   count of 12 precludes that currently.
   - Continue diltiazem drip w/ PRN lopressor when not controlled.
   - Consider amiodarone or digoxin.  Amiodarone would likely be more
   effective, but may cause cardioversion and it is impossible to know
   without a TEE or prolonged anticoagulation whether he has a [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **]
   [**Last Name (Prefixes) 5624**].  Digoxin may be more realistic at this point.
   - Control fever as much as possible
   - Continue diuresis as creatinine allows.
   - Daily weights
   - Appreciate cardiology input
   #. Hypoxia:
   Patient with new oxygen requirement in the last few days. Currently
   mid-90s on 3L NC. Pulmonary exam with upper airway coarse sounds and
   bilbasilar crackles. Possible that hypoxia is all due to pulmonary
   edema from poor LV filling in setting of LVH and tachycardia.  This
   hypothesis supported by worsening hypoxia when tachy to 150s.
   - Control HR and BP as above
   - Diuresis as creatinine allows.
   #. Multiple Myeloma s/p now stem cell transplant:
   Patient is SCT day +7.  Will likely nadir until days [**12-19**].
   - Appreciate BMT team input into further management
   - Transplant precautions
   - Low bacteria diet
   #. Febrile neutropenia:
   Patient's ANC now 0. Patient persistently febrile on micafungin,
   cefepime, daptomycin and acyclovir.
   - Neutropenic precautions
   - Continue neupogen until ANC greater than 1000
   - Continue micafungin (currently day 5), cefepime (currently day 8),
   daptomycin (currently day 4), acyclovir (currently day 9)
   #. VRE UTI:
   Urine culture positive from [**2112-1-23**]. Sensitive to linezolid;
   however, BMT did not want to use linezolid due to marrow suppression.
   Daptomycin sensitive, so dapto started on [**2112-1-26**].
   - ID consult input appreciated
   - Continue daptomycin (currently day 4)
   - Await urine culture sensitivities for daptomycin
   #. Hypertension:
   Normal ventricular function on Echo. Patient has not had hypotension
   during her current course.
   - Additional diuresis as above
   - Consider afterload reduction with IV hydralazine once HR controlled
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Regular low bacteria diet as allowed by her mucositis, TPN

   - Bowel regimen will be added as needed
   - Pain management with PRN morphine IV

She is currently in the ICU with tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, febrile neutropenia, altered mental status, and pulmonary edema. The patient underwent stem cell transplantation on day +7 and is expected to have a nadir until days 12-19. She also has a urinary tract infection caused by vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE).

1. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status may be consistent with delirium, but there is a concern for possible CNS infection due to her febrile neutropenia. Further evaluation is needed, and an MRI may be considered if there is ongoing concern for infectious etiologies of altered mental status (AMS).

2. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia appears to be in atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Possible causes include volume overload and fever. Efforts should be made to control her heart rate and blood pressure, and consideration should be given to anticoagulation once her platelet count improves.

3. Hypoxia: The patient is experiencing hypoxia, which may be related to pulmonary edema. Controlling her heart rate and blood pressure, as well as continuing diuresis as creatinine allows, are important management strategies.

   #. Fevers: Patient continues to have high-grade fevers despite

   possible CNS infection.  Patient  is febrile and neutropenic, so

   is worsening.  CT head was normal, without evidence of bleed, despite
   her thrombocytopenia.  Her agitation drives her tachycardia, so we have
   been intermittently using morphine, ativan and haldol to calm her.  She
   is nearly non-verbal, making it difficult to assess her pain.

   platelet count of 12 precludes that currently.

   - Hold off on diuresis for today given hyponatremia and rising

   Patient with new oxygen requirement in the last few days. Currently

   edema from poor LV filling in setting of LVH and tachycardia.  Diuresis

Summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and multiple myeloma, who presents to the ICU with tachycardia to 180s this AM in the setting of multiple refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier in the hospital course. She is currently on a diltiazem drip for rate control, and her blood pressure is 126/52 mmHg.

The patient has altered mental status, most consistent with delirium, though fevers are concerning for possible CNS infection. Her agitation drives her tachycardia, so she has been intermittently using morphine, ativan, and haldol to calm her. She is nearly non-verbal, making it difficult to assess her pain. 

The patient also has pulmonary edema, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and febrile neutropenia. She is day +7 post stem cell transplant and will likely nadir until days 12-19. She is febrile with a temperature of 103.6°F and her white blood cell count is low at 0.1 K/uL. Her platelet count is also low at 15 K/uL.

Her current medications include diltiazem, furosemide (Lasix), lorazepam (Ativan), hydromorphone (Dilaudid), meperidine (Demerol), and haloperidol (Haldol). She has had multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and is currently in AF with RVR. 

Her recent lab results show a sodium level of 120 mEq/L, potassium level of 3.4 mEq/L, and chloride level of 98 mEq/L. Her BUN is elevated at 36 mg/dL, creatinine is 1.4 mg/dL, and glucose is 124 mg/dL. Her WBC count is 0.1 K/uL, HCT is 21.6%, and PLT is 49 K/uL.

Imaging studies reveal bilateral pleural effusions, possibly increased on the right, and a cardiac silhouette likely unchanged allowing for differences in lung volumes. There are signs of fluid overload similar to the previous day's chest x-ray.

The patient's urine culture is positive for a VRE UTI, which is sensitive to linezolid. However, the BMT team does not want to use linezolid due to marrow suppression. Daptomycin is sensitive, so it has been started. The patient's blood cultures are negative for growth.

The patient's recent vital signs include a temperature of 103.6°F, heart rate of 107 bpm, blood pressure of 126/52 mmHg, respiratory rate of 40 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on 3L NC.

   Assessment and Plan
   75-year-old woman with history of hypertension and multiple myeloma,
   presents to ICU with tachycardia to 180s in setting of multiple
   refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier in hospital
   course.   No intubated to facilitate procedures given continued
   agitation in setting of fevers and likely bacteremia.
   #. Fevers: Patient continues to have high-grade fevers despite
   treatment with broad-spectrum abx.  Cannot give Tylenol PO or PR.
   Toradol worked but has renal toxicity.  Only using cooling blanket at
   this point.  UTI VRE is daptomycin sensitive, so unlikely to be source
   - Culture once daily while spiking.
   - Give Demerol for rigors, using sparingly given low GFR.
   - Continue [**Month/Year (2) 8023**]/[**Last Name (un) 614**]/micafungin/acyclovir for antibiotic coverage.
   Now also with azithromycin, primaquin and clinda per ID
   - Consider LP today if able to get platelets > 50K.
   #. Altered mental status:
   Most consistent with delirium, though fevers are concerning for
   possible CNS infection.  Patient  is febrile and neutropenic, so
   encephalitis or meningitis could be contributing.   Her mental status
   is worsening.  CT head was normal, without evidence of bleed, despite
   her thrombocytopenia.  Her agitation drives her tachycardia, so we have
   been intermittently using morphine, ativan and haldol to calm her.  She
   is nearly non-verbal, making it difficult to assess her pain.
   - LP today as above
   - Will keep antibiotics at doses for CNS penetration.
   - f/u MRI results
   - Daptomycin unlikely cause of delirium.
   #. Tachycardia:
   Today appears to be in Afib with RVR. We thought her tachycardia was
   exacerbated by volume overload, though today she appears dry and
   remains tachy with a cloudy CXR.  Complicating her tachycardia is
   continued fever.  Dig loaded yesterday.  CHADS2 score is 2 (age and
   hypertension), so she will eventually require consideration for
   anticoagulation, though platelet count of 12 precludes that currently.
   - Continue Digoxin.
   - Control fever as much as possible
   - Hold off on diuresis for today given hyponatremia and rising
   creatinine.  Do not give back fluid given tenuous respiratory status.
   - Daily weights
   - Appreciate cardiology input
   #. Hypoxia: Patient with new oxygen requirement in the last few days.
   Pulmonary exam with upper airway coarse sounds and bilbasilar crackles.
   Possible that hypoxia is all due to pulmonary edema from poor LV
   filling in setting of LVH and tachycardia.  Diuresis has been limited
   by hyponatremia and rising Cr.  This hypothesis supported by worsening
   hypoxia when tachy to 150s.  Patient now intubated with FiO2 60%.
   - wean FiO2; given neutropenia will defer placing a line and follow
   peripheral O2 sat
   - Control HR and BP as above
   - Diuresis as creatinine allows.
   #. Multiple Myeloma s/p now stem cell transplant:
   Patient is SCT day +9.  Will likely nadir until days [**12-19**].
   - Appreciate BMT team input into further management
   - Transplant precautions
   - Low bacteria diet
   #. Febrile neutropenia:
   Patient's ANC now 0. Patient persistently febrile on micafungin,
   meropenem, daptomycin and acyclovir, with new abx added yesterday.
   - Neutropenic precautions
   - Continue neupogen until ANC greater than 1000
   - Continue micafungin (currently day 7), cefepime/meropenem (currently
   day 10), daptomycin (currently day 6), acyclovir (currently day 11)
   #. Hypertension:
   Normal ventricular function on Echo. Patient has not had hypotension
   during her current course.
   - Additional diuresis as above
   - Consider afterload reduction with IV hydralazine once HR controlled
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: TPN on hold for now
   Glycemic Control:  insulin SS

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and multiple myeloma. She was admitted to the ICU with refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation and is currently intubated due to agitation, altered mental status, discomfort, and the need for tests.

The patient continues to have high-grade fevers despite treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics. Her laboratory results show leukopenia (low white blood cell count), thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), and hyponatremia (low sodium levels). Imaging shows moderate right and small left pleural effusions, relatively symmetric bilateral airspace opacities, small pericardial effusion, and nonspecific mesenteric and perinephric stranding.

The patient's medical complications and potential medical complications include:

1. Fevers: The patient's persistent high-grade fevers suggest a possible ongoing infection despite antibiotic treatment. This could indicate the need for further investigation and adjustment of the antibiotic regimen.

2. Altered mental status: The patient's worsening mental status is concerning for possible delirium or central nervous system (CNS) infection. Given her febrile and neutropenic state, encephalitis or meningitis could be contributing factors. Further evaluation with a lumbar puncture (LP) is planned if platelets are above 50K.

3. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia appears

   Imaging: [**1-30**] CT Chest/Abd/Pel:
    1. Moderate right, and small left layering pleural effusions,
   increased since the prior chest CT.
   2. Relatively symmetric bilateral airspace opacities, perihilar
   predominant, which may reflect infection or pulmonary edema, worse
   since the prior study. Interlobular septal thickening at the lung
   apices indicates pulmonary edema.
   3. Small pericardial effusion.
   4. Nonspecific mesenteric and perinephric stranding. While this could
   relate to an infectious process such as pyelonephritis, or
   pancreatitis, this may be related to a generalized anasarca. Clinical

   Assessment and Plan
   75-year-old woman with history of hypertension and multiple myeloma,
   presents to ICU with tachycardia to 180s in setting of multiple
   refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier in hospital
   course.   Now intubated to facilitate procedures given continued
   agitation in setting of fevers and likely infection.
   #. Fevers: Patient continues to have high-grade fevers despite
   treatment with broad-spectrum abx.  UTI VRE is daptomycin sensitive, so
   unlikely to be source
   - Culture once daily while spiking.
   - Tylenol PRN
   - Give Demerol for rigors, using sparingly given low GFR.
   - Continue [**Month/Year (2) 8023**]/[**Last Name (un) 614**]/micafungin/acyclovir for antibiotic coverage.
   Now also with azithromycin, primaquin and clinda per ID
   - Consider LP today if able to get platelets > 50K.
   .
   #. Hypoxia/Respiratory failure: Patient with new oxygen requirement in
   the last few days. Pulmonary exam with upper airway coarse sounds and
   bilbasilar crackles.  Patient now intubated with FiO2 60%.
   - wean FiO2; will get ABG now and use VBGs along with peripheral SaO2
   to wean vent settings
   - Control HR and BP as above
   - Diuresis on hold for now given worsening renal failure.
   #. Altered mental status:
   Most consistent with delirium, though fevers are concerning for
   possible CNS infection.  Patient  is febrile and neutropenic, so
   encephalitis or meningitis could be contributing.   Her mental status
   is worsening.  CT head was normal, without evidence of bleed, despite
   her thrombocytopenia.  Her agitation drives her tachycardia, so we have
   been intermittently using morphine, ativan and haldol to calm her.  She
   is nearly non-verbal, making it difficult to assess her pain.
   - LP today as above
   - Will keep antibiotics at doses for CNS penetration.
   - f/u MRI results
   - Daptomycin unlikely cause of delirium.
    .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Most likely pre-renal/ATN from sepsis.
   - will follow I/O and CVP
   - prn fluid boluses for low UOP
   - urine lytes
   - renally dose meds
   - consider renal u/s if persists
   .
   #. Tachycardia:  Afib with RVR. We thought her tachycardia was
   exacerbated by volume overload, as well as fever and agitation.  Dig
   loaded yesterday.  CHADS2 score is 2 (age and hypertension), so she
   will eventually require consideration for anticoagulation, though
   platelet count of 12 precludes that currently.
   - Continue Digoxin.
   - Add diltiazem PO and titrate up as needed for better rate control
   - Control fever as much as possible
   - Daily weights
   - Appreciate cardiology input
   #. Multiple Myeloma s/p now stem cell transplant:
   Patient is SCT day +9.  Will likely nadir until days [**12-19**].
   - Appreciate BMT team input into further management
   - Transplant precautions
   - Low bacteria diet
   #. Febrile neutropenia:  Patient continues to be neutropenic and
   persistently febrile on micafungin, meropenem, daptomycin and
   acyclovir, with new abx added yesterday.
   - Neutropenic precautions
   - Continue neupogen until ANC greater than 1000
   - Continue micafungin (currently day 7), cefepime/meropenem (currently
   day 10), daptomycin (currently day 6), acyclovir (currently day 11)
   #. Hypertension:
   Normal ventricular function on Echo. Patient has not had hypotension
   during her current course.
   - Hold on diuresis for now as above
   - Consider afterload reduction with IV hydralazine once HR controlled
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: TPN on hold for now, will request tube feed recs
   Glycemic Control:  insulin SS

Summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and multiple myeloma, who presented to the ICU with tachycardia and refractory atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. She has been intubated due to agitation and potential procedures. She has high-grade fevers despite broad-spectrum antibiotics and is suspected to have an infection. She is febrile and neutropenic, making her at risk for CNS infection. Her mental status is worsening, and she may have delirium or encephalitis/meningitis. She has acute renal failure likely due to sepsis, hypertension, and possible volume overload. She has a history of multiple myeloma and recently underwent a stem cell transplant. She is currently on multiple antibiotics, antifungals, and antivirals.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Fevers: The patient continues to have high-grade fevers despite treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics. This indicates that the infection has not been fully controlled, and further investigation is needed to identify the source of infection.
2. Hypoxia/Respiratory failure: The patient requires supplemental oxygen and is intubated with FiO2 60%. Weaning of FiO2 should be done carefully, and ABG analysis should guide the weaning process.
3. Altered mental status: The patient is experiencing worsening mental status, which could be due to delirium or a possible CNS infection

The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of multiple myeloma who underwent an autologous stem cell transplant (auto-SCT). She presents with febrile neutropenia, altered mental status (AMS), and rapid atrial fibrillation (AF). The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to acute respiratory failure. She also has pulmonary edema, hypertension, and pancytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Opportunistic infection: The patient's immunocompromised state due to neutropenia and pancytopenia increases the risk of opportunistic infections. Extensive coverage with antibiotics, antifungals, and antivirals is being provided, and cultures are pending.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's worsening renal function may be pre-renal or due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN) from sepsis. Close monitoring of intake and output, urine electrolytes, and consideration of renal ultrasound if persistent are recommended.
3. Central nervous system (CNS) infection: Given the patient's AMS and risk of CNS infection, a lumbar puncture (LP) has been planned to rule out CNS infection.
4. Prolonged mechanical ventilation: The patient's acute respiratory failure necessitates ongoing mechanical ventilation support. Weaning off FiO2 and adjusting ventilator settings will be important for successful extubation.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The

Summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of multiple myeloma who underwent an autologous stem cell transplant. She is currently in the ICU with several medical conditions, including febrile neutropenia, altered mental status (AMS), rapid atrial fibrillation (AF), acute respiratory failure, and acute renal failure. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation. She has multiple lines and tubes inserted, including a tunneled line, and is receiving multiple medications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Opportunistic infection: The patient's immunocompromised state due to chemotherapy and stem cell transplant increases the risk of opportunistic infections. Extensive coverage with antibiotics, antifungals, and antivirals is being provided while awaiting culture results.
2. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's acute respiratory failure may progress to ARDS, which can cause severe lung dysfunction and potentially lead to multiorgan failure.
3. Delirium: The patient's AMS could be a result of sepsis or an underlying CNS infection. Delirium can worsen outcomes in critically ill patients.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's rapid AF and use of digoxin increase the risk of further cardiac arrhythmias. Monitoring and appropriate management are crucial.
5. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's renal function is worsening, which may progress to AKI. Close monitoring of fluid balance

   Multiple small areas of elevated T2 signal within the white

   Assessment and Plan
   75-year-old woman with history of hypertension and multiple myeloma,
   presents to ICU with tachycardia to 180s in setting of multiple
   refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier in hospital
   course.   Now intubated to facilitate procedures given continued
   agitation in setting of fevers and likely infection.
   #. Fevers: Patient continues to have high-grade fevers despite
   treatment with broad-spectrum abx.  UTI VRE is daptomycin sensitive, so
   unlikely to be source. CSF does not show clear evidence of infection.
   HSV PCR pending. BAL also unrevealing.
   - Culture once daily while spiking.
   - Tylenol PRN
   - Give Demerol for rigors, using sparingly given low GFR.
   - Continue dapto/[**Last Name (un) 614**]/micafungin/acyclovir for antibiotic coverage.
   Now also with azithromycin, primaquin and clinda per ID
   .
   #. Hypoxia/Respiratory failure: Patient with new oxygen requirement in
   the last few days. Pulmonary exam with upper airway coarse sounds and
   bilbasilar crackles.  Patient now intubated with FiO2 60%. CT shows
   possible mutlifocal infection, but BAL negative for bacterial cx, viral
   panel, legionella, nocardia, AFB smear, fungi, PCP. [**Name10 (NameIs) 11083**] pending.
   - wean FiO2
   - Control HR and BP as above
   - Diuresis on hold for now given worsening renal failure.
   #. Altered mental status:
   Most consistent with delirium, though fevers are concerning for
   possible CNS infection.  Patient  is febrile and neutropenic, so
   encephalitis or meningitis could be contributing.   Her mental status
   is worsening.  CT head was normal, without evidence of bleed, despite
   her thrombocytopenia.  Her agitation drives her tachycardia, so we have
   been intermittently using morphine, ativan and haldol to calm her.  She
   is nearly non-verbal, making it difficult to assess her pain. MRI
   showed small bihemispheric lesions more likely small infarcts but
   cannot rule out infection, as well as sinus disease.
   - LP unrevealing with normal protein and glucose, 0 wbc, HSV PCR
   pending.
   - Will keep antibiotics at doses for CNS penetration.
   - consider further evaluation of sinuses
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Appears pre-renal based on urine electrolytes.
   CVP 8, urine output borderline low.
   - will follow I/O and CVP
   - bolus 500cc NS
   - renally dose meds
   .
   #. Tachycardia:  Afib with RVR, exacerbated fever and agitation.
   CHADS2 score is 2 (age and hypertension), so she will eventually
   require consideration for anticoagulation.
   - Continue Digoxin.
   - increase diltiazem PO to 90 QID as tolerated by BP
   - Control fever as much as possible
   - Daily weights
   - Appreciate cardiology input
   #. Multiple Myeloma s/p now stem cell transplant:
   Patient is SCT day +10.  Counts beginning to increase today.
   - Appreciate BMT team input into further management
   - Transplant precautions
   - Low bacteria diet
   #. Febrile neutropenia:  Patient continues to be neutropenic and
   persistently febrile on micafungin, meropenem, daptomycin and
   acyclovir, with new abx added yesterday.
   - Neutropenic precautions
   - Continue neupogen until ANC greater than 1000
   - Continue micafungin (currently day 8), cefepime/meropenem (currently
   day 11), daptomycin (currently day 7), acyclovir (currently day 12)
   #. Hypertension:
   Normal ventricular function on Echo. Patient has not had hypotension
   during her current course.
   - increase diltiazem as above
   - Consider afterload reduction with IV hydralazine once HR controlled
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Fibersource HN (Full) - [**2112-1-31**] 10:00 PM 20 mL/hour

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and multiple myeloma. She presents to the ICU with tachycardia and multiple refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation. The patient is intubated due to continued agitation and likely infection.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the information provided are:

1. Fevers: The patient continues to have high-grade fevers despite treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics. This indicates an ongoing infection that needs further evaluation and management.

2. Hypoxia/Respiratory failure: The patient has a new oxygen requirement and shows signs of respiratory failure. The CT scan shows possible multifocal infection, but the BAL results are negative for bacterial, viral, Legionella, Nocardia, AFB smear, fungi, and PCP. This suggests the need for additional diagnostic tests or alternative treatment options.

3. Altered mental status: The patient is experiencing delirium, which could be consistent with delirium or a possible CNS infection. Given her febrile and neutropenic status, encephalitis or meningitis should be considered. The CT head is normal without evidence of bleed, but an MRI showed small bihemispheric lesions that may represent small infarcts or an underlying opportunistic infection. Further evaluation, including HSV PCR and LP, is pending.

4. Acute renal failure: The patient appears to have pre-renal acute renal failure

The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and multiple myeloma, who presented to the ICU with tachycardia and episodes of atrial fibrillation. She has been intubated due to agitation and fever. She has been diagnosed with multiple infections, including pneumonia, urinary tract infection, and sinusitis. The patient has undergone a stem cell transplant and is currently neutropenic. She also has acute renal failure and altered mental status.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Fevers: The patient continues to have high-grade fevers despite treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics. This may indicate an ongoing infection or resistance to the current antibiotics.
2. Hypoxia/Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and requires supplemental oxygen. There is a concern for multi-focal infection in the lungs, but BAL results have been negative for various pathogens.
3. Altered mental status: The patient is experiencing delirium, which is consistent with her infection. An LP has been performed, but results are pending. The patient's medications will be adjusted for better CNS penetration.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's urine output is low, and her CVP is within a normal range. Pre-renal causes of renal failure are suspected, but further evaluation is needed.
5. Tachycardia: The patient has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, exacerbated by fever and agitation. Anticoag

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of hypertension and multiple myeloma admitted to the ICU.
- She has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response following a transplant for multiple myeloma.
- The patient is experiencing respiratory failure, acute but not ARDS, with worsening multi-focal opacities and bilateral effusions.
- She has persistent fever and altered mental status.
- The source of infection is not clear, but extensive evaluations have been done without finding a clear source.
- The patient also has hypertension, benign altered mental status (not delirium), multiple myeloma (cancer), and tachycardia/atrial fibrillation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is worsening, indicated by multi-focal opacities and bilateral effusions. The cause of this failure may be pneumonia, possibly related to pulmonary pathology.

2. Tachycardia/Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has tachycardia and atrial fibrillation. It is being treated with digoxin, diltiazem, and other medications to control heart rate.

3. Altered Mental Status: The patient has persistent altered mental status, which is not delirium. The cause is unknown, and further investigations are pending.

4. Fever: The patient has had persistent fever, which has not been clearly sourced. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been given

   Assessment and Plan
   75-year-old woman with history of hypertension and multiple myeloma,
   presents to ICU with tachycardia to 180s in setting of multiple
   refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier in hospital
   course.   Now intubated.
   #. Fevers: Patient continues to have high-grade fevers despite
   treatment with broad-spectrum abx.  UTI VRE is daptomycin sensitive, so
   unlikely to be source, on day [**9-18**] of course. CSF does not show
   evidence of infection. HSV PCR pending. BAL also unrevealing, however
   chest CT shows multiple concering areas in chest. Patient also has SC
   line (uncle[**Name (NI) 2037**] what date this was placed). No NGT in place, so sinus
   changes on MRI less likely to be acute.
   - attempt to place PIV and D/C SC line
   - Culture once daily while spiking.
   - Tylenol PRN
   - Give Demerol for rigors, using sparingly given low GFR.
   - Continue azithromycin/dapto/[**Last Name (un) 614**]/micafungin/acyclovir for PNA and UTI
   coverage
   - D/C clinda and primaquine since ruled out for toxo and PCP
   .
   #. Hypoxia/Respiratory failure:  Patient now intubated with FiO2 40%,
   decreased from 60%. PSV trial this AM but patient became tachypnic (was
   spiking fever at the time). CT shows possible mutlifocal infection, but
   BAL negative for bacterial cx, viral panel, legionella, nocardia, AFB
   smear, fungi, PCP. [**Name10 (NameIs) 11083**] pending.
   - repeat PSV trial this PM when afebrile
   - if tachypnic, obtain ABG
   - Control HR and BP as above
   #. Altered mental status:
   Most consistent with delirium in setting of infection. MRI showed small
   bihemispheric lesions more likely small infarcts but cannot rule out
   infection, as well as sinus disease.
   - LP unrevealing with normal protein and glucose, 0 wbc, HSV PCR
   pending.
   - Will keep antibiotics at doses for CNS penetration.
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Appears pre-renal based on urine electrolytes.
   CVP 5-8, urine output borderline low.
   - will follow I/O and CVP
   - bolus 500cc NS
   - PM lytes
   - renally dose meds
   .
   #. Tachycardia:  Afib with RVR, exacerbated fever and agitation.
   CHADS2 score is 2 (age and hypertension), so she will eventually
   require consideration for anticoagulation.
   - Continue Digoxin.
   - increase diltiazem PO to 90 QID as tolerated by BP
   - Control fever as much as possible
   - Daily weights
   - Appreciate cardiology input
   #. Multiple Myeloma s/p now stem cell transplant:
   Patient is SCT day +10.  Counts beginning to increase today.
   - Appreciate BMT team input into further management
   - Transplant precautions
   - Low bacteria diet
   #. Febrile neutropenia:  ANC 600, and persistently febrile on
   micafungin, meropenem, daptomycin and acyclovir
   - Neutropenic precautions
   - Continue neupogen until ANC greater than 1000
   - Continue micafungin (currently day 8), cefepime/meropenem (currently
   day 11), daptomycin (currently day 7), acyclovir (currently day 12)
   #. Hypertension:
   Normal ventricular function on Echo. Patient has not had hypotension
   during her current course.
   - increase diltiazem as above
   - Consider afterload reduction with IV hydralazine once HR controlled
   ICU Care

Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and multiple myeloma. She presented to the ICU with tachycardia to 180s in the setting of multiple refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) earlier in the hospital course. The patient is now intubated.

The patient continues to have high-grade fevers despite treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics. The urine culture is positive for vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE), which is sensitive to daptomycin, making it unlikely to be the source of infection. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) does not show evidence of infection. HSV PCR is pending. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) also shows no signs of infection, but a chest CT reveals multiple concerning areas in the chest. The patient also has a subcutaneous (SC) line placed on an unspecified date, and no nasogastric tube (NGT) is in place, so sinus changes on MRI are less likely to be acute.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 39.5°C (103.1°F), heart rate (HR) of 92 bpm (with a range of 78-132 bpm), blood pressure (BP) of 95/44 mmHg (with a range of 57-165/38-97 mmHg), respiratory rate

   75-year-old woman with history of hypertension and multiple myeloma,
   presents to ICU with tachycardia to 180s in setting of multiple
   refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier in hospital
   course.   Now intubated.
   #. Fevers: Patient continues to have high-grade fevers despite
   treatment with broad-spectrum abx.  Still unclear source for infection,
   but still awaiting final culture results.  Only positive result is UTI
   VRE, which is daptomycin sensitive; this is day [**9-18**] for daptomycin
   course. CSF does not show evidence of infection. HSV PCR pending. BAL
   also unrevealing, however chest CT shows multiple concering areas in
   chest.  Hickman removed yesterday.
   -  Line holiday (just 3 peripherals)
   - Culture once daily while spiking.
   - Tylenol PRN
   - Give Demerol for rigors
   - Continue azithromycin/dapto/[**Last Name (un) 614**]/micafungin/acyclovir for PNA and UTI
   coverage
   - D/C clinda and primaquine since ruled out for toxo and PCP
   .
   #. Hypoxic/Respiratory failure:  Patient now intubated on CMV/ASSIT;
   failed PSV twice for unclear reasons.  Etiology of hypoxic status most
   likely from infectious source in lungs (multifocal infiltrates on CT,
   but BAL cultures negative so far) or transplant associated pneumonitis.
   - repeat PSV trial this AM when afebrile
   - if tachypnic, obtain ABG
   - Control HR and BP as above
   #. Altered mental status:
   Most consistent with delirium in setting of infection. MRI showed small
   bihemispheric lesions more likely small infarcts but cannot rule out
   infection, as well as sinus disease.
   - LP unrevealing with normal protein and glucose, 0 wbc, HSV PCR
   pending.
   - Will keep antibiotics at doses for CNS penetration
   - Will wean sedation when patient is more stable to better assess
   mental status.
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Appears pre-renal based on urine electrolytes,
   though cr. Is improving
   - will follow I/O and CVP
   - renally dose meds
   .
   #. Tachycardia:  Afib with RVR, exacerbated fever and agitation.
   CHADS2 score is 2 (age and hypertension), so she will eventually
   require consideration for anticoagulation.
   - Discontinue digoxin and start metoprolol.  Uptitrated today to 25mg
   TID
   - increase diltiazem PO to 90 QID as tolerated by BP
   - Control fever as much as possible
   - Daily weights
   - Appreciate cardiology input
   #. Multiple Myeloma s/p now stem cell transplant:
   Patient is SCT day +11.  Counts beginning to increase today.
   - Appreciate BMT team input into further management
   - Transplant precautions
   - Low bacteria diet
   - Consider d/c of neupogen
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and multiple myeloma. She was admitted to the ICU with tachycardia and multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation.

The patient continues to have high-grade fevers despite treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics. The source of infection is still unclear, but a urinary tract infection with vancomycin-resistant enterococcus (VRE) has been identified. The patient is currently receiving appropriate antibiotic coverage for this infection.

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis does not show any evidence of infection. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) results are also negative for infection. However, a chest CT scan reveals multiple concerning areas in the chest.

The patient's altered mental status is consistent with delirium, likely secondary to infection. An MRI showed small bihemispheric lesions that could be small infarcts or infection. The patient's renal function is showing signs of acute renal failure, which appears pre-renal in nature.

The patient's tachycardia is attributed to atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. She has a CHADS2 score of 2, indicating a need for consideration of anticoagulation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Infection: The patient has persistent fevers despite broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment. The source of infection is

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old female with multiple myeloma who has undergone bone marrow transplantation (BMT) and is currently admitted with atrial fibrillation and persistent respiratory failure.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the information provided include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure, which may be due to pulmonary edema and fluid centralization in the lungs. This is indicated by the rapid decline in lung compliance when reducing PEEP and pressure support levels.

2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. This condition can lead to poor cardiac output, hypotension, and potential embolic events.

3. Altered mental status: The patient is experiencing altered mental status, possibly due to sedation or an underlying infection. Close monitoring and gradual weaning of sedation are recommended.

4. Infection: The patient has persistent fevers despite empiric antibiotic coverage. Further investigations are needed to identify the source of infection, and antibiotic therapy may need to be adjusted based on culture results.

5. Multiple myeloma: The patient's underlying multiple myeloma may contribute to her susceptibility to infections and other complications. Treatment for the malignancy should continue as per the BMT protocol.

6. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) prophylaxis: The patient is at risk of developing DVT due to prolonged immobilization. Prophylactic measures such as

The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and multiple myeloma. She presents to the ICU with tachycardia and multiple refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation. She is now intubated. The patient continues to have high-grade fevers despite treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics. Her leukocyte count is markedly elevated. She has a urinary tract infection with vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE), which is sensitive to daptomycin. Other lab results show abnormalities in white blood cell count, hemoglobin, creatinine, electrolytes, and liver enzymes. Chest CT shows multiple concerning areas in the chest, and cultures are pending. The patient has been on multiple medications including azithromycin, daptomycin, micafungin, and acyclovir for pneumonia and urinary tract infection coverage. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Infection: The patient's persistent high-grade fevers and leukocytosis suggest ongoing infection despite broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment. It is important to identify the source of infection and adjust antibiotic therapy accordingly. Monitoring of cultures and clinical response is crucial.
2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure and presence of multifocal infiltrates on chest CT raise concern for ARDS. Close monitoring of oxygenation and respiratory status is necessary. Prone positioning and consideration for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) may

   Assessment and Plan
   75-year-old woman with history of hypertension and multiple myeloma,
   presents to ICU with tachycardia to 180s in setting of multiple
   refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier in hospital
   course.   Now intubated.
   #. Fevers: Patient continues to have high-grade fevers despite
   treatment with broad-spectrum abx.  Still unclear source for infection.
   Marked Leukocytosis today, although consistent with receiving Nupogen.
   Only positive result is UTI VRE, which is daptomycin sensitive; this is
   day [**10-19**] for daptomycin course. CSF does not show evidence of
   infection. Has only PIVs. C. dif neg. BAL also unrevealing, however
   chest CT shows multifocal infiltrates in chest, possibly [**3-9**] transplant
   associated pneumonitis.  Consider atypical mycoplasma which may take
   more time to grow on BAL samples. MRI also showed mutiple areas of
   small infarct vs. infection, but could not differentiate without
   contrast. Concern would be for septic emboli vs. primary intracranial
   infection, will repeat MRI today with gad.
   - MRI with gad
   - D/C acyclovir as HSV PCR neg
   - D/C migafungin as B-glucan/galactomannan neg
   - completed 5 d course of azithro today, will D/C
   - Continue dapto/[**Last Name (un) 614**] for PNA and UTI coverage
   -  Line holiday (just 3 peripherals)
   - Culture once daily while spiking
   - Tylenol PRN
   - Give Demerol for rigors
   .
   #. Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  Patient now intubated on CMV/ASSIT;
   failed PSV twice for unclear reasons.  Etiology of hypoxic status most
   likely from infectious source in lungs (multifocal infiltrates on CT,
   but BAL cultures negative so far) or transplant associated pneumonitis
   with large contribution from mental status. CXR shows pleural effusions
   c/w increased volume overload.
   - TBB even today
    - maintain on AC today since patient has large sedation requirements
   in setting of delirium
   .
   #. Altered mental status:
   Most consistent with delirium in setting of infection, now complicated
   by several days of high dose sedatives. Sedative requirement remains
   high, and patient becomes agitated when sedatives weaned.
   - Will obtain MRI as above.
   - start zyprexa 2.5-5mg TID PRN and attempt to decrease fentanyl/midaz
   - D/C lorazepam
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Pre-renal, creatinine trending down.
   - will follow I/O and CVP
   - renally dose meds
   .
   #. Tachycardia:  Afib with RVR, exacerbated by fever and agitation.
   CHADS2 score is 2 (age and hypertension), so she will eventually
   require consideration for anticoagulation.
   - uptitrate metoprolol to 37.5mg TID
   - cont diltiazem PO 90 QID
   - Control fever as much as possible
   - Daily weights
   - Appreciate cardiology input
   #. Multiple Myeloma s/p now stem cell transplant:
   Patient is SCT day +12.  Now has Leukocytosis.
   - Appreciate BMT team input into further management
   - Transplant precautions
   - Low bacteria diet
   ICU Care

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and multiple myeloma, presenting to the ICU with tachycardia and multiple refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation. She has been intubated and is currently on mechanical ventilation.

The patient continues to have high-grade fevers despite treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics. The source of infection is still unclear. She has leukocytosis, which could be consistent with receiving Nupogen. A urinary tract infection caused by vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) has been identified, and the patient is receiving daptomycin-sensitive treatment for it.

The patient's chest X-ray shows pleural effusions, indicating increased volume overload. She also has multifocal infiltrates in her chest, which could be transplant-associated pneumonitis or atypical mycoplasma infection. A chest CT scan reveals multiple areas of small infarct versus infection, but it is difficult to differentiate without contrast.

The patient's mental status is altered, most likely due to delirium in the setting of infection. She has been on high-dose sedatives for several days and has a high sedation requirement. The patient becomes agitated when sedatives are weaned.

Summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of multiple myeloma who underwent a bone marrow transplant (BMT) and was admitted to the ICU for hypoxemic respiratory failure and persistent fevers. The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation (AF), pulmonary edema, and fever. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged mechanical ventilation.
2. bloodstream infection due to indwelling catheters.
3. deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE) due to prolonged immobilization.
4. nosocomial infection due to immunosuppression from the BMT.
5. hepatic dysfunction due to drug toxicity or sepsis.
6. renal dysfunction due to drug toxicity, hypotension, or sepsis.
7. delirium or agitation due to sedative medications or underlying infection.
8. gastrointestinal bleeding or ulceration due to stress ulcer prophylaxis medications.

It is important to monitor the patient closely for any signs of deterioration and adjust the treatment plan accordingly. Regular assessment of vital signs, laboratory values, and imaging studies should be performed to detect any potential complications early on.

TEXT:
TITLE:
   Chief Complaint: ABX: Per BMT attending, only d/c'd micafungin
   (actually we stopped azithro also, but I don't think BMT cared about
   that, as it was ID's idea).  ID wanted to stop mica, dapto, acyclovir
   and azithro but held off per BMT recs.  ID attending came by in PM and
   said we should definitely stop dapto and acyclovir tomorrow (that will
   be 10 days dapto for VRE urine and CSF was HSV neg)

   Assessment and Plan
   75-year-old woman with history of hypertension and multiple myeloma,
   presents to ICU with tachycardia to 180s in setting of multiple
   refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier in hospital
   course.   Now intubated.
   #. Fevers: Pt had only low grade fevers x 24 hours.  No clear source
   for infection. Leukocytosis consistent with receiving Nupogen. Only
   positive result is UTI VRE, which is daptomycin sensitive; this is day
   10/10-14d. LP and BAL unrevealing. Chest CT shows multifocal
   infiltrates in chest, possibly [**3-9**] transplant associated pneumonitis vs
   multifocal PNA.  Consider atypical mycoplasma which may take more time
   to grow on BAL samples. MRI also showed mutiple areas of small infarct
   vs. infection, but could not differentiate without contrast. Concern
   would be for septic emboli vs. primary intracranial infection, will
   repeat MRI today with gad.
   - MRI with gad
   - Continue dapto for UTI (last dose today per ID), acyclovir (should
   also end today per ID) and [**Last Name (un) 614**] for PNA
   -  Line holiday (just 3 peripherals)
   - Culture once daily while spiking
   - Tylenol PRN
   - Give Demerol for rigors
   .
   #. Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  Patient now intubated on CMV/ASSIT;
   failed PSV twice for unclear reasons.  Etiology of hypoxic status most
   likely from infectious source in lungs (multifocal infiltrates on CT,
   but BAL cultures negative so far) or transplant associated pneumonitis
   with large contribution from mental status.
   - TBB even today
    - maintain on AC today since patient has large sedation requirements
   in setting of delirium
   .
   #. Tachycardia:  Afib with RVR.  CHADS2 score is 2 (age and
   hypertension), so she will eventually require consideration for
   anticoagulation.
   - cont metoprolol 37.5mg TID
   - cont diltiazem PO 90 QID
   - Daily weights
   - Appreciate cardiology input
   #. Altered mental status:
   Most consistent with delirium in setting of infection, now complicated
   by several days of high dose sedatives. Sedative requirement remains
   high, and patient becomes agitated when sedatives weaned.
   - Will obtain MRI as above.
   - start zyprexa 2.5-5mg TID PRN and attempt to decrease fentanyl/midaz
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Cr back at baseline.
   .
   #. Multiple Myeloma s/p now stem cell transplant:
   Patient is SCT day +13.
   - Appreciate BMT team input into further management
   - Transplant precautions
   - Low bacteria diet

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and multiple myeloma, currently in the ICU.
- She presented with tachycardia up to 180 beats per minute and refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.
- The patient was intubated and is currently on CMV/ASSIST ventilation.
- She has been experiencing fevers for the past 24 hours, but no clear source of infection has been identified.
- Laboratory results show leukocytosis, which may be due to receiving Nupogen.
- The patient has a UTI caused by Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE), which is sensitive to daptomycin. This is on day 10/10-14 days.
- Lumbar puncture (LP) and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) results are unrevealing.
- A chest CT scan shows multifocal infiltrates in the chest, possibly transplant-associated pneumonitis or multifocal pneumonia.
- An MRI also revealed multiple areas of small infarcts versus infection, but it could not differentiate without contrast.
- The concern is for septic emboli versus primary intracranial infection, so an MRI with gadolinium will be repeated today.
- The plan is to continue dapto for the UTI (last dose today per Infectious Disease), acyclovir (should also end today per ID), and

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and multiple myeloma. She was admitted to the ICU with tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, and refractory episodes. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to hypoxic respiratory failure. She also has fevers, leukocytosis, and a urinary tract infection caused by vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE), which is sensitive to daptomycin. The patient has multifocal infiltrates in her chest, possibly transplant-associated pneumonitis or pneumonia. An MRI showed multiple areas of small infarct versus infection, but could not differentiate without contrast. The patient's mental status is poor, and she is experiencing delirium. She also has acute renal failure with a rising creatinine level. The patient is day +13 post-stem cell transplant.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Infection: The patient has a urinary tract infection with VRE and multifocal infiltrates in her chest, suggesting a possible pneumonia. The patient is also febrile, indicating an ongoing infection.
2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may be due to volume overload, infectious causes (pneumonia), or transplant-associated pneumonitis. The patient failed non-invasive ventilation and required intubation.
3. Tachycardia: The patient has persistent tachycardia, likely secondary to

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old female with multiple myeloma who underwent bone marrow transplantation (BMT). She is currently in the ICU and experiencing respiratory failure, altered mental status, and fever. 

The patient's respiratory failure is characterized by persistent requirements for ventilatory and oxygenation support. She exhibits tachypnea (rapid breathing), tachycardia (rapid heart rate), and hypertension. Sedation has been held this morning for examination, and spontaneous breathing trials (SBT) will be conducted today. Arterial blood gas (ABG) will be monitored at 30 minutes of SBT.

The patient's fever is ongoing, with no identifiable source. Broad-spectrum antibiotics including meropenem, daptomycin, and acyclovir have been initiated. Acyclovir may be discontinued as herpes simplex virus (HSV) studies were negative. The course of meropenem and daptomycin will be completed based on ID recommendations.

The patient also has altered mental status, which is not delirium. Studies to date have been negative, and she is being treated with Zyprexa (antipsychotic medication) and sedation as needed.

In terms of potential medical complications, the patient's condition in the ICU poses several risks. These include ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and glycemic control issues. The patient is

   75-year-old woman with history of hypertension and multiple myeloma,
   presents to ICU with tachycardia to 180s in setting of multiple
   refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier in hospital
   course.   Now intubated.
   #. Fevers: Patient continues to have low grade fevers, and is currently
   afebrile at 98.6.  No clear source for infection, only urine that is
   positive for VRE (sensitive to daptomycin, and day [**12-18**] for this
   course).  Chest CT with multifocal infiltrates in chest, possibly [**3-8**]
   to transplant associated penumotnitis vs. multifocal PNA.  Consider
   atypical mycoplasma which may take more time to grow on BAL samples.
   MRI also showed mutiple areas of small infarct vs. infection, but could
   not differentiate without contrast.  MRI yesterday with no gross
   abnormalities
   - D/c daptomycin, as no evidence of resistant gram + bacteria at this
   time
   - Change acyclovir to prophylactic dose
   - Continue meropenem until sputum culture back
   - Continue
line holiday
   - Culture once daily while spiking
   - Tylenol PRN
   - Give Demerol for rigors
   .
   #. Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  Patient now on PSV, but failed
   extubation attempts twice in the last two days.  Etiology of hypoxic
   status most likely from volume overload, as well as possible infectious
   source in lungs (multifocal infiltrates on CT, but BAL cultures
   negative so far) or transplant associated pneumonitis with large
   contribution from mental status.
   - Lasix overnight
   - Continue on PSV
   - Extubation attempt this AM
   - NPO at MN
   .
   #. Tachycardia:  Afib with RVR.  CHADS2 score is 2 (age and
   hypertension), so she will eventually require consideration for
   anticoagulation.
   - increase metoprolol to 37.5mg TID
   - cont diltiazem PO 90 QID
   - Daily weights
   - Appreciate cardiology input
   #. Altered mental status:
   Most consistent with delirium in setting of infection, now complicated
   by several days of high dose sedatives. Sedative requirement remains
   high, and patient becomes agitated when sedatives weaned.
   - start zyprexa 2.5-5mg TID PRN and attempt to decrease fentanyl/midaz
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Cr back at baseline.
   .
   #. Multiple Myeloma s/p now stem cell transplant:
   Patient is SCT day +14.
   - Appreciate BMT team input into further management
   - Transplant precautions
   - Low bacteria diet

Summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and multiple myeloma, presenting to the ICU with tachycardia to 180s in the setting of multiple refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier in the hospital course. She is currently intubated.

The patient continues to have low-grade fevers, and is currently afebrile at 98.6. There is no clear source for infection, except for urine that is positive for VRE (sensitive to daptomycin) on day [**12-18**]. A chest CT shows multifocal infiltrates in the chest, possibly due to transplant-associated pneumonitis vs. multifocal PNA. Consider atypical mycoplasma, which may take more time to grow on BAL samples. An MRI also showed multiple areas of small infarct vs. infection, but could not differentiate without contrast. An MRI yesterday showed no gross abnormalities.

The medical team decided to:
- D/c daptomycin, as there is no evidence of resistant gram + bacteria at this time.
- Change acyclovir to a prophylactic dose.
- Continue meropenem until the sputum culture results are back.
- Continue holiday.
- Culture once daily while spiking.
- Tylenol PRN.
- Give Demerol for rigors.

Summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma, who presented to the ICU with fevers and agitation after undergoing a stem cell transplantation (SCT). The patient has been experiencing respiratory failure, pulmonary edema, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, altered mental status, and impaired skin integrity. The patient's medical history includes allergies to Percocet, ciprofloxacin, oxycodone, and rash; fever with Dr. [Doctor's Last Name]. The patient has been receiving various antibiotics and antiviral medications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's current condition of respiratory failure may lead to further complications such as hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
2. Pulmonary edema: The presence of pulmonary edema can increase the risk of respiratory distress and potential cardiac complications.
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may progress to a more serious arrhythmia, potentially leading to hemodynamic instability.
4. Hypertension: If left uncontrolled, the patient's hypertension can result in end-organ damage, including cardiovascular events.
5. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status, if not addressed, could lead to worsening confusion, increased risk of falls, and inability to maintain airway protection.
6. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity increases the risk of infections and pressure ulcers.
7. Multiple myeloma

   Assessment and Plan
   75-year-old woman with history of hypertension and multiple myeloma,
   presents to ICU with tachycardia to 180s in setting of multiple
   refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier in hospital
   course.   Now intubated.
   #. Fevers: Patient continues to have low grade fevers, and is currently
   afebrile at 98.6.  No clear source for infection, only urine that is
   positive for VRE (sensitive to daptomycin, and day [**12-18**] for this
   course).  Chest CT with multifocal infiltrates in chest, possibly [**3-8**]
   to transplant associated penumotnitis vs. multifocal PNA.  Consider
   atypical mycoplasma which may take more time to grow on BAL samples.
   MRI head yesterday without gross abnormalities.
   - D/c daptomycin, as no evidence of resistant gram + bacteria at this
   time
   - Change acyclovir to prophylactic dose
   - Continue meropenem until sputum culture back
   - Continue
line holiday
   - Culture once daily while spiking
   - Tylenol PRN
   - Give Demerol for rigors
   .
   #. Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  Patient now on PSV, but failed
   extubation attempts twice in the last two days.  Etiology of hypoxic
   status most likely from volume overload, as well as possible infectious
   source in lungs (multifocal infiltrates on CT, but BAL cultures
   negative so far) or transplant associated pneumonitis.  Other barriers
   to extubation include mental status, anxiety, and fatigue.
   - Patient received lasix overnight.
   - Continue on PSV
   - Extubation attempt today or tomorrow
   - Patient was NPO at MN for possible extubation today
   .
   #. Tachycardia:  Afib with RVR.  CHADS2 score is 2 (age and
   hypertension), so she will eventually require consideration for
   anticoagulation.
   - increase metoprolol to 50mg TID
   - cont diltiazem PO 90 QID
   - Daily weights
   - Appreciate cardiology input
   #. Altered mental status:
   Most consistent with delirium in setting of infection, now complicated
   by several days of high dose sedatives. Sedative requirement remains
   high, and patient becomes agitated when sedatives weaned.
   - zyprexa 2.5-5mg TID PRN
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Cr back at baseline.
   .
   #. Multiple Myeloma s/p now stem cell transplant:
   Patient is SCT day +14.
   - Appreciate BMT team input into further management

   - Low bacteria diet

Summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma who underwent bone marrow transplantation (BMT). He is currently hospitalized and suffering from respiratory failure, persistent fevers, and altered mental status. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated in the ICU. He has been on multiple antibiotics but still has a fever. His respiratory status remains unstable, with an unfavorable respiratory system compliance index (RSBI) and poor spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) attempts. The possible causes of respiratory failure include sedation, hypomagnesemia, generalized weakness, pulmonary hypertension, cardiac disease, or transplant-related cardiac or lung abnormalities.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is persistent and multifactorial. It is crucial to address the underlying causes such as sedation, hypomagnesemia, generalized weakness, and consider other possibilities like pulmonary hypertension, cardiac disease, or transplant-related complications.
2. Fever: The patient has persistent fevers with an isolated VRE (Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus) in the urine. It is essential to monitor the patient closely for any signs of infection and adjust antimicrobial therapy accordingly.
3. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status is altered, and it is unclear what the exact cause is. Sedating medications may be contributing to this condition. Further evaluation, including LP (lumbar puncture) and head MRI, may be necessary to determine the et

4. Tachycardia: The patient is experiencing tachycardia, specifically atrial fibrillation. The cause is unclear, but there is concern for possible thromboembolic disease as a precipitant. Monitoring of the heart rate is recommended, and diltiazem has been initiated to manage the tachycardia.

5. Multiple myeloma: The patient has a history of multiple myeloma and has undergone bone marrow

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and multiple myeloma. She was admitted to the ICU with tachycardia and multiple refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation. The patient is currently intubated.

The patient continues to have low-grade fevers, and there is no clear source of infection. However, her urine is positive for Vancomycin-resistant enterococcus (VRE) after completing a full course of daptomycin. The chest CT shows multifocal infiltrates in the chest, which may be transplant-associated pneumonitis or multifocal pneumonia. An MRI head did not reveal any gross abnormalities.

The patient has finished her course of daptomycin for VRE, and c.diff is negative. Acyclovir was changed to a prophylactic dose, and meropenem will continue until the sputum culture results are available. The patient's respiratory support includes being on pressure support ventilation (PSV) due to hypoxic respiratory failure. She has failed two extubation attempts in the last two days.

Renal function has improved, and diuresis will be aggressive today. The respiratory system compliance index (RSBI) is 28, and negative inspiratory force (NIF) is -20, indicating a need for increased training and better nutrition before considering extubation. The patient is currently NPO for possible extubation today.

Summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and multiple myeloma. She was admitted to the ICU with tachycardia to 180s in the setting of multiple refractory episodes of atrial fibrillation with RVR earlier in the hospital course. She is now intubated.

The patient continues to have low-grade fevers and is currently afebrile at 98.3. No clear source for infection has been identified, except for urine that is positive for VRE after completing a full course of dapto. A chest CT shows multifocal infiltrates in the chest, possibly transplant-associated pneumonitis or multifocal PNA. Consideration is being given to atypical mycoplasma, which may take more time to grow on BAL samples. An MRI head without gross abnormalities was performed.

The patient has finished her course of dapto for VRE. C.diff is negative yesterday, and acyclovir has been changed to a prophylactic dose. Meropenem will be continued until the sputum culture returns (day 1). The patient's line holiday will be continued, with cultures once daily while spiking. Tylenol will be given as needed for pain, and Demerol will be administered for rigors.

The patient is experiencing hypoxic respiratory failure and is currently on PSV but failed extubation attempts twice in the last two days. The etiology of hypoxic status is likely from volume
